title: 108_hr1800
content: The policy of the United States is to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by prohibiting their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. Prohibited acts and penalties are outlined in the legislation. Prohibited acts under the legislation include importing, exporting, or transporting fur from animals trapped in steel-jawed leghold traps, as well as selling or acquiring such traps. Violators face penalties of imprisonment or fines. SEC. 3. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to individuals providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Officers or employees of the government are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Act shall be enforced by the Secretary, who can utilize personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import and export violations will be treated accordingly. Enforcement authorities can take action, excluding violations under subsection (b). Enforcement authorities have the power to detain, search, and seize packages if there is reasonable cause to suspect a violation of the Act. They can also make arrests without a warrant if there is probable cause, and execute warrants issued by a judge for enforcement. Enforcement authorities have the power to detain, search, and seize packages if there is reasonable cause to suspect a violation of the Act. Any article of fur or conventional steel-jawed leghold trap taken in violation of this Act shall be subject to forfeiture to the United States. Enforcement authorities have the power to seize property under the customs laws of the United States, and the Attorney General can seek injunctions against those violating the Act. Cooperation is required from various government departments and agencies for effective enforcement. Enforcement authorities, including the Treasury and other relevant departments, must cooperate to ensure effective enforcement of this Act and its rules. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" refers to furskins or articles made from furskins, the term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" describes a specific type of animal trap, the term "customs laws of the United States" refers to laws enforced by the United States Customs Service, and "import" means bringing goods into the jurisdiction of the United States. The term "interstate commerce" is defined in section 10 of title 18, United States Code, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary has the authority to create rules for implementing the Act, and the Act will become effective one year after its enactment.
